prj:VisitConstraint.prj:note: We request for an observation as soon as possible within 4 weeks after triggering (see technical justification for more detail).

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We use default configuration for a continuum observation. We do not need spectral resolution.
The target is a point source, and does not need to be resolved.
We need to detect the polarized flux density of the band-3 continuum at about 10 sigma level. The total flux density is expected to be 10 mJy, and the polarized flux is 200 uJy, 2% of the total.

We trigger a TOO observation of this target (= science goal), when the ratio between the one-day averaged MAXI 4-10 keV and 2-4 keV photon fluxes exceeds 0.4 in the decaying phase (after the peak X-ray flux) in outbursts. These criteria correspond to the soft-to-hard transition and enables us to observe the low/hard state. We request to perform an ALMA obesrvation within 4 weeks (as soon as possible) after the TOO trigger (= the day when we contact the ALMA team), to ensure the detection of the polarized flux (>200 uJy) at about 10 sigma level with a reasonable exposure. Considering the scientific importance and impact to the operation of ALMA, we limit the maximum number of TOO triggers to 1 for this target and to 2 in total during the whole Cycle3 period (i.e., the total observing time is 3 hours/target * 2 target = 6 hours at the maximum.

We trigger a TOO observation of this target (= science goal), when the ratio between the one-day averaged MAXI 4-10 keV and 2-4 keV photon fluxes exceeds 0.6 in the decaying phase (after the peak X-ray flux) in outbursts. These criteria correspond to the soft-to-hard transition and enables us to observe the low/hard state. We request to perform an ALMA obesrvation within 4 weeks (as soon as possible) after the TOO trigger (= the day when we contact the ALMA team), to ensure the detection of the polarized flux (>200 uJy) at about 10 sigma level with a reasonable exposure. Considering the scientific importance and impact to the operation of ALMA, we limit the maximum number of TOO triggers to 1 for this target and to 2 in total during the whole Cycle3 period (i.e., the total observing time is 3 hours/target * 2 target = 6 hours at the maximum.

We need to detect the polarized flux density of the band-3 continuum at about 10 sigma level. The total flux density is expected to be 10 mJy, and the polarized flux is 200 uJy, 2% of the total.

We trigger a TOO observation of this target (= science goal), when the ratio between the one-day averaged MAXI 4-10 keV and 2-4 keV photon fluxes exceeds 0.7 in the decaying phase (after the peak X-ray flux) in outbursts. These criteria correspond to the soft-to-hard transition and enables us to observe the low/hard state. We request to perform an ALMA obesrvation within 4 weeks (as soon as possible) after the TOO trigger (= the day when we contact the ALMA team), to ensure the detection of the polarized flux (>200 uJy) at about 10 sigma level with a reasonable exposure. prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We use default configuration for a continuum observation. We do not need spectral resolution.
The target is a point source, and does not need to be resolved.
We need to detect the polarized flux density of the band-3 continuum at about 10 sigma level. The total flux density is expected to be 10 mJy, and the polarized flux is 200 uJy, 2% of the total.

We trigger a TOO observation of this target (= science goal), when the ratio between the one-day averaged MAXI 4-10 keV and 2-4 keV photon fluxes exceeds 0.7 in the decaying phase (after the peak X-ray flux) in outbursts. These criteria correspond to the soft-to-hard transition and enables us to observe the low/hard state. We request to perform an ALMA obesrvation within 4 weeks (as soon as possible) after the TOO trigger (= the day when we contact the ALMA team), to ensure the detection of the polarized flux (>200 uJy) at about 10 sigma level with a reasonable exposure. prj:VisitConstraint.prj:note: We request for an observation as soon as possible within 4 weeks after triggering (see technical justification for more detail).

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We use default configuration for a continuum observation. We do not need spectral resolution.

The target is a point source and does not need to be resolved. We recognize that the observation can be somewhat affected by shadowing, although the effect is not so significant with the C36-2 or more extended configurations.
We need to detect the polarized flux density of the band-3 continuum at about 10 sigma level. The total flux density is expected to be 10 mJy, and the polarized flux is 200 uJy, 2% of the total.

We trigger a TOO observation of this target (= science goal), when the ratio between the one-day averaged MAXI 4-10 keV and 2-4 keV photon fluxes exceeds 0.7 in the decaying phase (after the peak X-ray flux) in outbursts. These criteria correspond to the soft-to-hard transition and enables us to observe the low/hard state. We request to perform an ALMA obesrvation within 4 weeks (as soon as possible) after the TOO trigger (= the day when we contact the ALMA team), to ensure the detection of the polarized flux (>200 uJy) at about 10 sigma level with a reasonable exposure. Considering the scientific importance and impact to the operation of ALMA, we limit the maximum number of TOO triggers to 1 for this target and to 2 in total during the whole Cycle3 period (i.e., the total observing time is 3 hours/target * 2 target = 6 hours at the maximum.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: One of the biggest questions left in high energy astrophysics is the mechanism to form the relativistic jets from accreting black holes. Here we propose to carry out first TOO polarimetry of transient Galactic black hole X-ray binaries in the mm band, to study the magnetic field structures of compact, steady jets ubiquitously seen in low mass accretion rates. To trigger the observations, we monitor the X-ray lightcurves and spectra of our targets using the Japanese all-sky X-ray monitor MAXI. The ALMA's high sensitivity enables us for the first time to detect the polarized synchrotron component in the mm band and to constrain the magnetic field configuration at the base of the jets. We are also preparing for simultaneous multi-wavelength observations including X-ray, near-infrared and optical bands. They are expected to provide great synergy with the ALMA observations, by allowing us to reveal the structure of the inner accretion disk, as well as to estimate the magnetic field strength and energy distribution of electrons at the jet base.

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Graduate School of Science, Kyoto University
